metadata.title: Numerical modeling of nano enhanced PCM solidification in an enclosure with metallic fin

sections.text:
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
Solidification process of Nano enhanced phase change material (NEPCM) is
simulated in existence of radiative heat transfer. H2O and CuO are utilized as PCM and nanoparticles, respectively. Finite element method with adaptive mesh is employed to simulate this transient problem. Effects of fin length, size of nanoparticle, nanofluid volume fraction, radiation parameter on solidification process have been investigated. Results indicate that solidification rate enhances by dispersing CuO nanoparticles in to water. As L and Rd augments, solidification process is completed in lower time and total energy reduces.
Keywords: Nanoparticle; Thermal radiation; FEM; Nano enhanced PCM; Solidification.
Nomenclature
PCM Phase change Material Fluid density
1 Corresponding author: Email: mohsen.sheikholeslami@nit.ac.ir , mohsen.sheikholeslami@yahoo.com (M. Sheikholeslami)

1. Introduction
High heat transfer performance and energy storage density are two important
keys for a thermal energy storage system. In order to store a huge amount of energy during solidification, Latent heat thermal energy storage (LHTES) can be utilized. Various applications can be mentioned for LHTES. There is one limitation for LHTES and it is poor thermal properties of PCMs. Adding nanoparticles to PCM can overcome to this limitation. Lacroix [1] presented the performance of a shell-and-tube LHTES unit with a finned tube. They utilized enthalpy method for finding the impact of fins on the thermal behavior of the unit. Sciacovelli and Gagliardi [2] investigated melting of PCM in a storage system with new shapes of fines. They presented optimize design to reach uniform phase change process. Erek et al. [3] simulated the influence of radial fins in a storage system. They proved that phase change rate
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
enhance about 20% if fins are properly chosen. Chiu and Martin [4] investigated parametric study to find the best design of a shell-and-tube LHTES unit. They proved that 40% reduction of melting time was obtained by halving the fins spacing. Ijaz et al. [5] investigated nanoparticle migration in a wavy channel. They utilized two phase model for nanoflduid. Abdulhameed et al. [6] simulated nanofluid flow in existence of both electric and magnetic field. Ellahi et al. [7] investigated ferrofluid flow over a starching disk in existence of Lorentz forces. Sheikholeslami and Shehzad [8] utilized the non-equilibrium model for nanofluid flow in a porous media. They used single phase model for nanofluid. Garoosi et al. [9] utilized nanofluid for cooling process. Selimefendigil and Oztop [10] presented the role of titled angle on conjugate heat transfer.
Bhatti et al. [11] demonstrated two phase flow in presence of magnetic field.
They considered the electric double layer impacts which are due to peristaltic propulsion. Mehmood et al. [12] investigated water based nanofluid mixed convection heat transfer in a porous media. They employed magnetic field to control the nanofluid migration. Zeeshan et al. [13] studied the thermal radiation effect on ferrofluid behavior over a plate in existence of magnetic dipole. Sheremet et al. [14] used Boussinesq-Darcy approximation for porous cavity. Sheikholeslami [15] presented the mesoscopic study to show the effect of Lorentz forces on nanofluid flow in a porous channel. He found that Nusselt number enhances with rise of Hartmann number. Kamran et al. [16] examined the effect of joule heating on nanofluid magnetohydrodynamic flow. They employed the slip boundary conditions for velocity profile. Impact of radiation parameter on nanoparticles migration was illustrated by Sheikholeslami et al. [17]. Chamkha and Ismael [18] investigated the nanofluid conjugate Heat Transfer in a porous medium. Shah and Khan [19] studied
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
the non-Newtonian flow over an oscillating sheet. They used Caputo–Fabrizio derivatives for this problem. Chamkha et al. [20] demonstrated nanofluid thermal radiation heat transfer over a porous wedge. Sheikholeslami [21] considered the Brownian motion effect on nanofluid flow inside a porous cavity. He found that convective flow enhances with increase of Darcy number. Khalid et al. [22] investigated ferrofluid flow over a porous sheet with ramped wall temperature. They utilized cylindrical shape nanoparticles. Different publications have been published about nanofluid applications [23-27].
In this paper, influences of thermal radiation on NEPCM solidification rate
have been simulated. Finite element method is employed to show simulate this unsteady problem. Roles of diameter of nanoparticles, nanofluid volume fraction, fin length and amplitude are illustrated.
2. Problem statement
Fig. 1 depicts the geometry of the current LHTESS and boundary conditions. The gap between inner wall and outer one filled with NEPCM. The initial temperature of NEPCM is equal to 278𝐾 and temperature of cold wall is 240K. Properties of PCM and CuO are depicted in table 1.
3. Governing Equations
In solidification process, buoyancy forces have no sensible effect and this term can be neglect in this unsteady phenomenon. So, the unsteady solidification process has following equations:

4. Numerical approach and validation
Current solidification process is simulated via standard Galerkin Finite Element Method (FEM). Adaptive mesh is employed to simulate the solidification process. The final algebraic system is solved by Newton-Raphson method. Each scalar can be calculating on corners of cells. For unsteady problems, an implicit Backward Difference Method is utilized. Fig. 2 depicts the adaptive mesh for this transient problem. To validation of this code, the outputs are compared with previous article (Ismaeil et al. [28]). Fig. 3 indicates good accuracy of present code.
5. Results and discussion
In order to expedite solidification process, NEPCM has been used in this paper.
Thermal radiation term is added in energy equation. Also, metallic fins help this
unsteady process. Influences of length of the fin  8 16L mm to mm , diameter of
nanoparticle 30 ,40 ,50pd nm nm nm , radiation parameter 0,0.5,1Rd  and
nanofluid volume fraction 0 0.04to  on rate of solidification are demonstrated.
Fig. 4 illustrates the impact of adding CuO nanoparticles in to H2O on
solidification front. Fig. 5 shows the influence of volume fraction of nanofluid on average temperature, solid fraction and total energy. This figure proves that using NEPCM instead of pure PCM has significant impact on solidification rate. Because conduction heat transfer is dominant in this transient process. Effect of  on solidification rate
enhances in greater time. Total energy and average temperature reduces by adding CuO nanoparticles. Minimum values of solid fraction occur at start of this process but opposite are true for average temperature.
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
Figs. 6 and 7 show the influence of L and pd on isotherms and solid fraction
contours. Fig. 8 shows the effect of pd on Phase change front. Average temperature,
solid fraction, total energy for various values of L and pd are demonstrated in Fig. 9. As
L enhances, solidification is completed in lower time. Thermal penetration depth is improved by using higher L , solidification rate is high, which reduces full
solidification time. As 40pd nm , increasing this parameter can augment the rate of
solidification but opposite trend is observed for 40pd nm . It means that 40pd nm
is optimum value for this parameter. As L augments, total energy decreases. Besides,
results show that maximum energy storage capacity belongs to 40pd nm , so rate of
solidification is higher than other cases.
Effects of radiation parameter on solid fraction and isotherms contours are
shown in Fig. 10. Figs. 11 and 12 show the impact of Rd on solidification front, average temperature, solid fraction and total energy. Radiation parameter has direct relationship with solidification rate. As Rd augments, solidification process takes shorter time and thermal penetration depth is increases.
Fig. 13 demonstrates the influences of , , pL Rd d and  on full solidification
time. The below formula can be obtained according to simulation data:

Increasing nanofluid volume fraction leads to accelerate solidification rate due to
enhancing in thermal conductivity. pd has optimum value near the 40nm. Using
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
bigger nanoparticle has reverse effect on solidification rate. Also full solidification time reduces with rise of L and Rd . As these parameters enhance, penetration depth increases.
6. Conclusion
Galerkin finite element method is utilized to simulate the transient
solidification of NEPCM in an enclosure with metallic fins. Effects of radiation parameter, fin length, diameter of nanoparticles and nanofluid volume fraction on solidification process are investigated. Results show that using nanoparticles can expedite solidification process. Using longer fin leads to accelerate solidification rate due to enhance in conduction mode. Average temperature of NEPCM reduces with augment of Rd and .

Highlights CuO-water nanofluid solidification is investigated. FEM is used to simulate this unsteady problem. Brownian motion effect is considered to calculate knf. Solidification rate increase with increase of φ and L. Average temperature decreases with augment of Rd.

referenceMentions.context: [5] investigated nanoparticle migration in a wavy channel.
[6] simulated nanofluid flow in existence of both electric and magnetic field.
[7] investigated ferrofluid flow over a starching disk in existence of Lorentz forces.

[20] demonstrated nanofluid thermal radiation heat transfer over a porous wedge.

metadata.abstractText: Solidification process of Nano enhanced phase change material (NEPCM) is simulated in existence of radiative heat transfer. H2O and CuO are utilized as PCM and nanoparticles, respectively. Finite element method with adaptive mesh is employed to simulate this transient problem. Effects of fin length, size of nanoparticle, nanofluid volume fraction, radiation parameter on solidification process have been investigated. Results indicate that solidification rate enhances by dispersing CuO nanoparticles in to water. As L and Rd augments, solidification process is completed in lower time and total energy reduces.
